positive.review: Played this game thinking it was about maths but I was instead reminded of my abusive childhood. Would recommend.

Heh.. i LOVE geometry dash almost as much as i like pokemon 34! all i do all day is just play GEOMETRY DASH and play ALL of the self-play levels EVERY DAY!! Im nearing 3k hours and i just LOVE this game! all the old people wanting to connect with children is a trait i agree with in this games vast and overwhelmingly greasy player base! I play this game for 15 hours every day, its all i do! I wake up in my puddle of baby batter from last night and get on to play GEOMETRY DASH for the next 15 hours and yell at my family who want me to 'shower' and 'eat something that isnt canned'. But my life is super fulfilling because i have my miku body pillow with me all the time. She loves me for who i am with all the dried yogurt and babies included, and i love to play my GEOMETRY DASH with her EVERY DAY.

Geometry Dash is one of those games you open ‚Äújust for a bit‚Äù and suddenly you‚Äôre fighting for your life. It looks simple, just tap to jump and follow the beat, but the levels are brutal. Some of the levels are just drop dead gorgeous, an absolute cinema. And there‚Äôs something satisfying about finally passing a part that kept embarrassing you. The music keeps you pumped, the visuals are clean and every failure somehow makes you hit retry without thinking. Annoying, addictive and honestly kind of a vibe.

The game is excellent, replayable, and you can even create your own levels!
I've played enough and, unfortunately, am disappointed with this game...

Disclaimer: I understand that the game was developed by one person and that game development is not only difficult but also a lengthy process.

But I have something to say about this, at the very least, the account saving is the worst thing about it.
I spent 2 months trying to save my account and still can't save for some strange reason. I thought I was banned, but the Boomlings website itself works perfectly fine for me, and I haven't received any complaints about rule violations. I can even see that I'm on the global leaderboard, which proves I'm not banned.

Either the saving feature itself works extremely poorly... Why not use Steam Cloud? Because saving my account, which, mind you, is only 5 megabytes, would be saved much faster than your current saving system, which has stopped saving my progress.

The level editor itself is also quite and extremely good, but there are moments that cause irritation rather than enjoyment of the creation process.
I'm not talking about visual bugs that don't really change anything literally; we can keep quiet about them and happily ignore them. But I'm talking about bugs that are irritating and you don't understand what the problem is, only to find out the problem was the editor's lack of polish. And you don't get satisfaction from solving the problem, but rather irritation that the fault wasn't yours, but that the developer apparently doesn't want to fix this bug. At the very least, the last patch came out a year ago, so it seems the developer simply doesn't care about fixing those issues that irritate the user, which is very unpleasant, actually.

Level Ratings
I would also complain about the developer rating levels poorly, but recently I realized that this might be partly the right decision.

I am often annoyed that, for example, an Easy level in the game is essentially Auto, where you make a couple of jumps and that's it.
Or that an Insane level feels more like a Hard, Harder level.
I would like to say that it's strange how the level ratings are based on a very strange premise.

Think about it - Hard literally means a "difficult" level, right? So why does it feel like I'm playing something on the level of Back on Track?
And I'm saying this as a casual player, not a hardcore one, so I was interested in the reason for this strangeness.

In the end, I understood the reason for the strange ratings.
Since the game is rated 3+, RobTop is ensuring safety for children who would see the game and try to play it. If a child is very impatient, they might break their computer or tablet out of frustration. If I were a parent and saw such a situation, I would be quite unhappy with the result that my child found some silly game and sacrificed a gadget. Therefore, RobTop decided to make the rating system safe and made it extremely casual, specifically for children aged 3+.

The true level rating system exists in the Map Packs, where you can indeed see many people dissatisfied that an "Easy" level is difficult for them. Or that a "Hard" level is truly Hard, not Easy.
It's a pity that Map Packs are an extremely underrated feature, because that's where you find genuine criticism of levels that were rated as excellent. But now the rating system is set to poor quality... a shame.

Login system is broken
I used to play this game a lot back in college (2014-2015 ish)

Just recently tried to get back into it because I've got a few friends that play
and have been unable to log into my old account.  I've verified that I have the correct email, username, etc, and I've reset the password multiple times, and gone through all of the other relevant troubleshooting steps, and all it ever gives me is "login failed".  I know the old account still exists because I've had my friends look it up and verify it.  I even joined the official discord and opened a support ticket on the matter.... two weeks ago...
the only response I got was a staff member replying "I don't tackle account issues much"
I've seen multiple other similar tickets opened in the time since and ALL of them have been ignored.  This isn't just a "me problem", its an issue with the login system.

I'd love to be able to submit a positive review, but I remember this system being problematic and broken last time I played it, too, over ten years ago.  Seeing that it's still broken this many years later is discouraging, to say the least.

Geometry Dash has all the ingredients of a great skill-based platformer‚Äîtight level design, a strong community, and endless replay value. Unfortunately, none of that matters when the game consistently fails at the most basic requirement of its genre: reading your inputs.

I‚Äôm playing on a $200 keyboard, and yet Geometry Dash regularly acts like I‚Äôm using a bargain-bin controller from 2004. Simple, precise taps‚Äîespecially on orbs‚Äîjust don‚Äôt register. You hit the spacebar or click exactly when you‚Äôre supposed to, and the game just‚Ä¶ ignores it. No jump, no feedback, nothing. In a game where success depends on frame-perfect timing, having inputs vanish into the void makes many levels feel less like a test of skill and more like an exercise in pure frustration.

Miss a timing because you messed up? Fine, that‚Äôs on you.
Miss a timing because the game decided your input wasn‚Äôt good enough for reasons unknown? Completely unacceptable.

What‚Äôs worse is that these input issues aren‚Äôt rare. They happen regularly enough to ruin the experience‚Äîeven on official levels. It‚Äôs hard to enjoy a rhythm-based platformer when the rhythm between your fingers and the game is constantly out of sync.

Geometry Dash could be great, but until it stops ghosting my inputs like a bad relationship, it's staying firmly in the ‚Äúunplayable‚Äù category for me.
